content:
re :I then just selected all my yahoo folders and pulled them into my Local Folders in T-bird.

You 'moved' all your emails that were in an imap folder connecting to server into the 'Local Folders' mail account. So you moved emails off the server.

Imap account folders synchronise with server folders and can only show whatever is on server.

If you want to get copies of important emails into the 'Local Folders' mail account: In an imap folder, right click on a batch of highlighted emails and use 'COPY TO' and select the relevant folder in 'Local Folders' account. Then check you have good copies. If it fails then at least you can recopy them.

If you want to put copies of emails back on server then do the above in reverse. Select batches of highlighted emails in the 'Local Folders' account and use the 'COPY TO' and select an imap account folder. Please note uploading back onto a server may take a while as servers do tend to have limits on how much can be uploaded via imap.

content:
Oauth relies on tokens which have been saved after a successful oauth process, which requires the correct password. Thereafter, neither a login nor a password is needed until the token expires, which is determined by the server being accessed.

david said
I believe Oauth2 requires a different password for each PC.

Passwords don't vary, but tokens do. In other words, the string that must be provided to the oauth password prompt will be the same in every case. However, a successful oauth process will save a token in Thunderbird, which is unique at the time it is saved.

That said, I think it is possible to copy tokens from one PC to another. It should be easy to test.
